Erik.Action: Threatens Helga with a sword and attempts to intimidate her.
Fumbles awkwardly while holding sword and undoing trousers, showing clumsiness rather than menace.
Responds defensively and rudely to Helga's questions about his behavior.
Fumbles trying to hold his sword to Helga's throat while undoing his trousers, showing difficulty managing two tasks at once.
Claims confidently to have experience in looting and pillaging, though this is met with skepticism.
Expresses shock and hesitation about the idea of rape, admits preference for mutual feeling between people.
Threatens Helga to keep quiet about not raping her, showing awkwardness and discomfort with the situation.
Dismisses killing and looting as necessary evils to fund expeditions without moral reflection.
Hesitates and shows uncertainty about his intentions and feelings towards Helga, struggling to assert himself confidently.
Attempts to justify his actions pragmatically by explaining the need to kill and loot to fund expeditions, showing some practical reasoning.
Threatens Helga in a confused and contradictory manner, indicating poor communication and emotional control.
Tells Helga to stop talking as if they were married, makes a crude joke about not feeling like raping her.
Vents frustration on a shattered door, encourages Helga to scream louder.
Looks up at Helga after she lies to save his face about rape.
Leaps to Helga's defense when two Vikings attack her, pulls Jennifer off despite her fighting back.
Vents frustration on a door, uses sarcasm and crude humor in conversation.
Leaps to Helga's defense when she is attacked, physically intervenes to protect her.
Appears stunned and unprepared when the other Vikings attack, momentarily passive before acting.
Leaps to Helga's defense, pulling Jennifer off her.
Runs Jennifer through in a fight, showing violent aggression.
Runs Ernest through without hesitation to protect Helga.
Inadvertently runs Helga through, causing her fatal injury.
Cradles Helga's head and tries helplessly to staunch her bleeding.
Questions Helga about her accusation and her name, showing concern and confusion.
Looks at Helga's dead body and the surrounding carnage with a somber, reflective expression.
Runs Jennifer through in a fight, decisively dealing with an opponent.
Runs Ernest through without hesitation, showing decisiveness and combat skill.
Accidentally kills Helga while trying to save her, showing a critical error in judgment or skill.
Tries to staunch Helga's bleeding and cares for her in her final moments, showing compassion but limited medical skill.
Fails to prevent further violence and chaos around him, appearing helpless and overwhelmed.
Frowns at the Vikings hurling axes at a frightened girl, showing disapproval of their cruel behavior.
Frowns disapprovingly at the reckless and dangerous behavior of other Vikings, showing awareness and concern.
Stares in astonishment and experiences a brief vision of Helga, the girl he accidentally killed, then shakes his head and lets the vision pass.
Reacts with disgust to the violent brawl in the Mead Hall and eventually leaves the scene, showing disapproval of the aggression.
Reacts with disgust to the violent brawl and eventually leaves the Mead Hall, showing restraint and disapproval of the chaos.
Does not intervene or attempt to stop the fight despite his apparent disapproval, instead choosing to walk away.
Questions the purpose of violence and pillaging, showing reflective and sincere doubt about his culture's values.
Calls out anxiously for Freya and searches for her, showing concern and care.
Questions the purpose of Viking raids and reflects deeply on their meaning, showing introspection and critical thinking.
Admits to having killed the girl Freya, seemingly shocked and horrified by his own action, indicating a serious mistake or misunderstanding.
Actively searches for Freya by running through the snow and climbing to a remote cave, demonstrating determination and resourcefulness.
Admits to uncertainty and reflects thoughtfully on Freya's words and the world around him.
Does not respond to Freya's mocking tone and instead engages sincerely in conversation.
Shows puzzlement and openness when Freya questions him about the seasons and the sun.
Questions Freya thoughtfully about the nature of the world and the past, showing reflective thinking.
Responds to Freya's probing questions with some uncertainty and puzzlement, indicating limited understanding of his environment.
Follows Freya to the cave mouth and engages in conversation despite feeling unsure, showing willingness to learn.
Admits he has never seen the sun and only recalls a vague childhood dream, showing a lack of direct experience and knowledge.
Earnestly asks Freya if there is anything men can do to stop the Age of Ragnarok, showing concern for others' fate.
Determines to wake the gods to save the world, demonstrating sincere hope and responsibility.
Pushes through a crowd to separate two fighting men, intervening to stop violence.
Determines that the current time is the Age of Ragnarok by observing the environment and connecting it to the prophecy.
Expresses earnest enthusiasm and determination to wake the gods despite Freya's implied doubt about his knowledge.
Seeks guidance from Freya and listens carefully to her instructions about the Horn Resounding.
Hesitates after receiving the quest instructions, showing some doubt or caution.
Pushes through a crowd to separate two fighting men, taking initiative to intervene in a violent situation.
Pushes through the crowd to separate Sven and Thorfinn and stop their fight.
Questions both Sven and Thorfinn about their fear of death, showing concern for their well-being.
Commands them to stop fighting when they crash into the pig-sty.
Ignores the crowd's hostility and attempts to intervene despite being pulled away.
Pushes his way through the crowd and separates Sven and Thorfinn to stop their fight.
Attempts to reason with Thorfinn and Sven by asking if they fear death, trying to defuse the situation through dialogue.
Fails to prevent Sven and Thorfinn from resuming their fight despite his efforts.
Is pulled away by others and unable to maintain control over the escalating conflict.
Dives back to keep Sven and Thorfinn apart to prevent a fight.
Proposes a plan where nobody gets killed, showing concern for others' safety.
Uses physical force to stop antagonists, laying them out to make a point.
Challenges others by asking if they are afraid to try crossing the Rainbow Bridge, putting them on the defensive.
Encourages his companions to join him on a dangerous and unprecedented journey, showing confidence and inspiring others.
Grins after persuading others against their initial reluctance, indicating a friendly and motivating demeanor.
Proposes a bold and unprecedented journey to the Halls of the Gods, confidently admits not knowing how but willing to try, and successfully persuades others to join him.
Directs the repair and outfitting of the Viking ship Golden Dragon, showing leadership and practical involvement in preparations.
Attempts to comfort the villagers before departure, urging them not to grieve despite dangers ahead.
Struggles to find the right words and fails to fully console the villagers, resulting in more crying.
Addresses the villagers before departure but struggles to deliver a confident and inspiring speech, resulting in increased crying and distress among the crowd.
Smiles broadly and waves to the tearful villagers, trying to be cheerful despite the grim situation.
Pleases the crowd by asking them to keep calm and not despair about their possible deaths.
Turns for a last salute and utters a hopeful farewell, showing respect and care for the villagers.
Tries to calm the distraught villagers by asking them to keep calm and offering a hopeful perspective about their fate.
Fails to come up with something cheerful immediately when prompted by his Grandad, showing hesitation and lack of quick wit.
Responds appropriately to Grandad's advice to leave and prepares to depart with a last salute, showing acceptance and leadership.
Dismisses the women's concerns about Keitel's assistant Loki, insisting Loki is capable despite their dislike.
Intervenes in quarrel between Thorfinn and Sven, trying to stop their bickering.
Reassures the women that Keitel's assistant Loki can handle the blacksmithing tasks, showing confidence in Loki's skills.
Fails to notice the women's clear discomfort and the social dynamics around Keitel's popularity, indicating a lack of social awareness.
Attempts to mediate the quarrel between Thorfinn and Sven over seating, but his repeated questioning shows a lack of understanding of the importance of the issue to the men.
Organizes seating arrangements for the group, trying to accommodate everyone despite limited space.
Tells Sven's dad 'We haven't got a spare place' but then finds a spot for him, showing some initial bluntness but eventual accommodation.
Responds sharply with 'Well, you ARE!' to Ivar's offer to give up his place, showing a brusque tone.
Acknowledges Snorri's point about seating arrangements and adjusts accordingly, showing flexibility and consideration.
Tells Sven's dad to 'Shut up' when he complains about seating, showing impatience and lack of tolerance.
Ultimately says 'It doesn't matter' about the division of beards and moustaches, showing a tolerant and easygoing attitude.
Organizes seating arrangements efficiently despite challenges, quickly adapts to new information, and maintains authority.
Ignores the aesthetic imbalance of seating (all big ones on one side, beards on one side, moustaches on the other) and dismisses concerns about it.
Reluctantly accepts his mother's pillow, a sentimental object from his father, despite embarrassment.
Raises his hand in a half-goodbye to the girl he killed, showing a moment of respect or remorse.
Reluctantly accepts the pillow from his mother despite embarrassment, showing respect and consideration.
Hesitates before taking the pillow, showing some indecision.
Gives a confident shout to start the voyage, taking charge of the moment.
Encourages the sea-sick crew to row despite their condition, showing insistence on action over comfort.
Notices the approaching threat and alerts the crew promptly, demonstrating responsibility and care for their safety.
Notices a suspicious sail on the horizon and immediately orders the crew to prepare to row despite their sea-sickness.
Insists on action and commands the crew firmly even though most are reluctant and ill.
Acts decisively and confidently in a potentially dangerous situation.
Looks at Keitel with contempt, dismissing his concerns.
Gives clear orders to Thorfinn and Keitel, asserting authority without explanation.
Manhandles Ivar to take up drumming, pushing him into action despite Ivar's discomfort.
Encourages Ivar to row despite his illness and fear, showing urgency but little empathy.
Commands his crew decisively despite confusion and doubt, asserting authority that cannot be argued with.
Recognizes the speed disadvantage of his ship but quickly identifies and uses a natural environmental feature (sea mist) to attempt escape.
Grins encouragingly and urges the men to row faster despite their fear.
Silences Ivar's drum to avoid detection, showing consideration for the group's safety.
Gives up on the useless lodestone without frustration and shares discovery of the Gates of the World with the men.
Grins confidently in the face of danger and commands the crew to row faster, showing leadership and calm under pressure.
Leans on the steering oar and makes a tactical decision to silence the drum and stop rowing, successfully evading Halfdan's ship.
Tries to use the fish-lodestone to find direction but gives up when it fails and throws it away, showing practical judgment in abandoning a useless tool.
Recognizes the Gates of the World and understands they have entered the Unknown, demonstrating awareness and navigation skill.
Points out the sun in the mist, showing observation and presence of mind in an unfamiliar environment.
Questions whether the sun should behave unusually, showing alertness to abnormal situations.
Warns others to look out before the monster attacks, demonstrating quick thinking and protective instincts.
Calms the crew by instructing them to row slower and more steadily despite the panic.
Commands the crew to row and then wisely instructs them to slow down to a manageable pace, showing control and awareness under pressure.
Maintains composure and gives clear, calm instructions during a chaotic attack, preventing further panic.
Commands the crew to keep rowing and stay focused despite panic.
Recognizes the fear of his crew and takes responsibility to save the situation.
Uses a pillow given by his mother as a symbol to inspire hope and courage.
Commands the crew to row faster and keep up the strike despite panic.
Recognizes the critical moment and takes initiative to save the situation.
Has an idea involving the pillow given by his mother and acts on it quickly.
Shins up the mast holding the pillow, showing decisiveness and confidence.
Takes initiative to climb the mast and bravely approach the dragon's nose to disable it.
Uses humor and friendly teasing when talking to the dragon ('Go on! Breathe in, you cod-brain!').
Focuses on practical action to protect the group rather than showing overt emotional warmth or friendliness in this excerpt.
Climbs the mast and swings onto the dragon's nose, showing physical skill and bravery.
Shoves a pillow up the dragon's nostril and stabs it with his sword, effectively incapacitating the dragon.
Commands the crew to row despite the chaos, showing leadership and decisiveness.
Leaps back across the mast and tries to control the situation by telling everyone to hold tight and get back to prevent tipping the boat.
Does not show visible happiness when cheered by others after the boat is catapulted into the sky, indicating possible concern or seriousness.
Repeatedly commands the crew to get back to prevent the boat from tipping, showing responsibility and care for others' safety.
Is dislodged and left dangling over the open sea, showing vulnerability but no indication of selfishness or abandonment.
Commands the crew to hold tight during the Dragon's sneeze, showing presence of mind in a sudden crisis.
Warns the crew to get back to prevent tipping, demonstrating awareness of danger and attempt to maintain control.
Fails to prevent the crew from rushing to one side, resulting in the boat tipping and crew members falling into the sea.
Ends up dislodged and hanging by his hands over the open sea, indicating loss of physical control and precarious situation.
Encourages the crew to keep bailing water despite the dire situation, saying 'Well, come on!'
Despite being dislodged and falling into the ship's hull, he quickly recovers, removes his helmet, and starts bailing water to save the ship.
Fails to hold on at the mast and falls into the ship, causing damage that leads to the ship taking on water.
Encourages the group by affirming their effort and bravery despite impending doom.
Asks Thorfinn not to let him drown, showing trust and reliance on a comrade.
Pauses in the act of killing Thorfinn and looks around, showing hesitation and possibly valuing life over violence.
Encourages the crew to face death bravely, showing leadership and resolve.
Pauses in the moment of crisis to assess the situation and notices the ship is not fully submerged, indicating situational awareness.
Commands 'Wait! Nobody kill anybody!' to prevent violence among Vikings.
Reassures others by calmly correcting Ivar's panic about the Dragon and points out the sun and blue sky.
Responds incredulously and with concern when the girl is found without weapons, showing protective instincts.
Commands 'Wait! Nobody kill anybody!' to prevent violence, showing leadership and control in a tense situation.
Correctly identifies the sun and the blue sky, calming others' panic and confusion.
Leads the group to cautiously approach the sleeping girl, instructing to get her weapons, showing tactical caution and concern for safety.
Expresses incredulity that the girl has no weapons, indicating a possible bias or assumption rather than open-mindedness.
Refuses to harm the girl and suggests making friends instead.
Questions the concept of friendship but remains open to it.
Responds suspiciously to the girl's welcome but does not react with hostility.
Refuses to attack the girl and suggests making friends instead, showing restraint and a diplomatic approach.
Questions the situation and the identity of the place and people, showing curiosity and critical thinking.
Responds suspiciously to the girl's welcome, indicating cautiousness and awareness.
Listens to Aud's urgent plea about the swords and asks questions to understand the situation.
Admits ignorance about the local customs and the curse on Hy-Brasil.
Fails to understand the significance of the swords and the curse on Hy-Brasil, shows confusion and lack of knowledge about the consequences of spilling blood.
Asks clarifying questions about the curse, showing some attempt to understand the situation.
Politely declines the court's offer to sing, expressing appreciation but explaining urgency.
Responds skeptically to the idea of a society with no killing and constant niceness, showing disbelief.
Shows polite but firm dismissal of the court's singing and redirects focus to their quest for the Horn Resounding, demonstrating clear priorities and social tact.
Repeats obvious statements ('Well, OBVIOUSLY there's no killing.') without adding insight, showing a lack of deeper engagement or critical thinking in the conversation.
Diplomatically asks King Arnulf and his court to sing for them, despite not genuinely wanting to hear it, to maintain politeness and goodwill.
Admits to biting a lie when pressed about sincerity, showing some discomfort with dishonesty.
Diplomatically tries to convince King Arnulf and his court to sing by carefully choosing words and showing awareness of the need for tact.
Swallows hard and bites a lie when pressed to confirm sincerity, showing discomfort and possible lack of confidence in the deception.
Smiles reassuringly at King Arnulf despite the awful din from the musicians.
Responds politely to King Arnulf's despair by saying the music was 'very... er, nice.'
Smiles reassuringly at King Arnulf despite the awful din from the musicians, maintaining composure and supporting others.
Responds to King Arnulf's despair with a polite but vague compliment ('No, no... It was very... er, nice.'), showing social tact but not addressing the problem directly.
Decides to be honest with King Arnulf about not liking the music.
Tries to explain his world and situation to the King despite the King's rude reaction.
Feels he is making a mess of diplomacy but continues to engage sincerely.
Decides to be honest with King Arnulf despite the risk of offending him.
Attempts to handle a delicate diplomatic situation by shifting focus to the quest for the Horn Resounding.
Feels he is making a mess of diplomacy, showing some self-awareness but also uncertainty.
Gives up on trying to please the King with music, indicating a limit to his diplomatic skill.
Engages in a sincere conversation with Aud about love and trust, showing vulnerability and honesty.
Focuses repeatedly on whether Aud has been to bed with someone else, seeming fixated and somewhat insensitive to her feelings.
Engages in a somewhat awkward and repetitive conversation about love and past relationships, showing confusion and fixation on literal meanings rather than emotional understanding.
Responds quickly to the sound of Ivar's horn and rushes to the window to assess the approaching threat, showing alertness and situational awareness.
Blurts out 'Fifth...' revealing the secret despite knowing the risk.
Blurts out 'Fifth...' revealing the secret despite being signaled to be quiet, causing potential trouble.
Stands petrified and naked with a cloak hanging awkwardly, showing lack of composure under pressure.
Responds to Aud's sincere offer to help with teasing and disbelief.
Leaps out of the way quickly to avoid danger (ship arriving), but inadvertently knocks over a chest.
Dismisses the significance of the Cloak Invisible, calling it 'the fifth one this week' and questioning its specialness.
Shows hesitation and uncertainty about whether to believe Aud's sincere offer to help him get to Asgaard.
Urgently warns others about Halfdan the Black's approach, showing concern for their safety.
Struggles and protests when restrained by the musicians, indicating a desire to act for the group's benefit.
Does not respond with hostility or insults to being roughly handled, instead focuses on the threat.
Dismisses King Arnulf's skepticism and continues to warn about Halfdan, showing persistence but possibly intolerance of doubt.
Races to the window and immediately recognizes the threat of Halfdan's ship approaching, insists on preventing the landing.
Attempts to leave quickly to act on the threat despite others' objections.
Is easily captured and restrained by the King's musicians without successfully evading or resisting effectively.
Struggles and protests captivity but fails to escape or convince captors to release him.
Clearly communicates the danger posed by Halfdan the Black and explains his motives to King Arnulf.
Warns others about the danger posed by Halfdan the Black, showing concern for their safety.
Urgently asks to be released when restrained, indicating distress but no aggression.
Expresses disbelief that Thorfinn could feel fear, showing a protective or caring attitude.
Calms his fearful crew by rationalizing the situation and deciding to use their own 'magic' to counter the enemy's trick.
Leaps into action alone to find a solution, showing responsibility and care for his men.
Climbs the wall with great effort to reach Aud's room, showing determination and trust in Aud by asking for help.
Is miffed when Aud points out the easier stairs, showing some impatience or stubbornness.
Realizes the enemy's power is a trick, not magic, and tries to calm his men.
Decides to use 'magic' of their own to counter the enemy's advantage, showing adaptability and leadership.
Leaps out of the ship and races to the city to find a solution, showing initiative and decisiveness.
Climbs the sheer cliff wall using daggers without hesitation, demonstrating physical skill and determination.
Fails to notice the stairs leading up to Aud's tower before climbing the wall, indicating a lack of situational awareness.
Takes the Cloak Invisible without fully understanding its limitations, determined to stop Halfdan despite warnings.
Waves to Aud after landing safely, showing gratitude for the cloak.
Races over and grabs the cloak despite not fully understanding its properties.
Leaps out of a forty-foot window parachuting down safely using the cloak.
Fails to realize the cloak only works on Aud's father and not on himself.
Acts decisively to stop Halfdan, showing confidence and initiative.
Leaps into the Golden Dragon brandishing the Cloak Invisible to boost morale and show readiness.
Uses humor and camaraderie by holding up the Cloak Invisible and engaging with others.
Leaps into the Golden Dragon brandishing the Cloak Invisible and confidently declares he has magic to match Halfdan the Black's magic.
Commands the crew to row out of the harbor decisively despite the tense situation.
Grins round at his men, sharing the moment of suspense and triumph with them.
Enjoys the moment of suspense, imagining he has vanished, showing playful interaction with his men.
Uses the Cloak Invisible to create a distraction and then leaps confidently onto the enemy ship, surprising both his men and the enemy.
Grins triumphantly imagining he has vanished, but most of his men are puzzled and skeptical about the effect of the Cloak Invisible.
Makes silly faces at enemy dog-soldiers and dances to lighten the mood.
Breaks into a little dance and acts playfully despite being in a hostile situation.
Leaps boldly onto enemy ship and confidently interacts with enemy soldiers, using humor and playfulness to unsettle them.
Behaves as if invisible, which confuses enemies and allows slaves to seize weapons and keys, indirectly aiding the attack.
Engages in silly faces and dancing rather than direct combat, showing unconventional tactics that prove effective.
Runs boldly into battle, fighting dog-soldiers and showing fearless leadership.
Playfully thinks he's revealing himself while wearing the Cloak Invisible, showing a lighthearted and sincere side.
Swings across the deck yelling 'I am the air! I am the wind!' demonstrating enthusiasm and spirited friendliness.
Runs through enemies, kills one, kicks another overboard, approaches enemy leader confidently, uses Cloak Invisible strategically, swings across deck on a rope while shouting boldly.
Leaps into the galley-pit and dispatches Eilif with a single thrust, avenging Ivar's death quickly and effectively.
Fights bravely alongside comrades and slaves, showing solidarity in battle.
Is outraged by the dog-soldier's treachery, indicating a sense of fairness and honor.
Is totally non-plussed upon seeing Loki disguised as a dog-soldier, showing openness and lack of suspicion.
Continues fighting a last enemy dog-soldier alone, showing persistence and combat skill.
Is stabbed in the back by an enemy, indicating a moment of vulnerability or lack of awareness.
Responds with outrage and quickly turns on the assassin, showing quick reaction and combat readiness.
Is totally non-plussed upon seeing Loki disguised as a dog-soldier, showing surprise but not panic.
Shows vulnerability by admitting confusion and faints when realizing others could see him despite his Cloak Invisible.
Politely and tactfully requests to borrow the Horn Resounding instead of demanding or taking it.
Fails to realize that others can see him despite wearing the Cloak Invisible, faints from the shock of this realization.
Approaches King Arnulf diplomatically and tactfully requests to borrow the Horn Resounding, showing social awareness and negotiation skill.
Politely requests to borrow the Horn Resounding rather than demanding or taking it.
Expresses surprise and humility about the size of the horn, showing sincerity and openness.
Successfully negotiates to borrow the Horn Resounding from King Arnulf, demonstrating social skill and confidence.
Is visibly surprised and unprepared for the size of the Horn Resounding, showing a momentary lack of foresight.
Affirms he can play the horn when questioned, indicating readiness and skill.
Warns others by shouting 'Look out!' just before a wall of water crashes through the Great Hall.
Urgently warns the citizens that Hy-Brasil is sinking despite their denial and complacency.
Leaps onto a wall and shouts urgently to the crowd that Hy-Brasil is sinking, trying to warn them despite their denial.
Questions the complacent citizens who refuse to acknowledge the danger, showing awareness and initiative.
Warns the crowd about the sinking island despite being ignored.
Looks around in despair as others ignore the danger.
Swims to rescue drowning people along with companions.
Leaps onto a wall and warns the crowd about the sinking island, showing awareness and urgency.
Looks around in despair when the authorities dismiss the danger, indicating frustration but no immediate effective action.
Swims quickly with companions to rescue drowning people, actively engaging in a life-saving effort.
Urgently tells people to get on board the ship to escape danger.
Shoos Harald away when he tries to comfort Aud.
Commands people to get on board the ship in a crisis situation.
Shoos away Harald Missionary offering help during a crisis.
Tries to blow the Horn Resounding first despite initial failure, showing determination.
Tries to separate Sven and his dad during their struggle.
Attempts to blow the Horn Resounding first despite initial failure, showing willingness to lead and try.
Fails to produce the correct sound on the horn, resulting in a pathetic spluttering.
Tries to intervene and separate Sven and his dad during their quarrel, showing conflict management and leadership.
Flings himself at the steering oar to steer the ship wildly and avoid crashing into a rock.
Shouts to clarify that they blew the Horn Resounding, trying to assert truth amid chaos.
Does not intervene to stop the escalating conflict and violence between Loki and Keitel.
Flings himself at the steering oar to avoid crashing into rocks, showing quick reflexes and control under pressure.
Shouts confidently that they blew the Horn Resounding, indicating awareness and confidence in their mission.
Appears confused and asks 'What are you talking about?' when others accuse Aud, showing some lack of understanding of the situation.
Tries to separate Loki and Keitel to prevent violence.
Supports Aud's plea for tolerance and warns against hatred.
Despite being stabbed, he does not retaliate immediately and instead focuses on the group's direction.
Questions others about the way to Asgaard, showing openness to others' knowledge.
Tries to separate Loki and Keitel to prevent violence.
Is momentarily distracted by Aud and Freya, allowing Loki to stab him.
Despite injury, quickly assesses the situation and questions others about the way to Asgaard.
Decides to pay out the rope to prepare for the journey over the Edge of the World.
Insists on looking over the Edge despite warnings and others' fear.
Notices Sven and Keitel trembling and seems aware of their fear.
Edges the ship further into the mist and over the Edge of the World despite the fear and warnings of others.
Insists on looking into the abyss despite Aud's warning that it will sap his strength.
Decides to believe in Aud and throws the rope away, trusting her.
Wakes the other Vikings up from their frozen stupor, showing concern for their well-being.
Decides to believe in Aud and throws the rope away, initiating the ship's journey over the Edge of the World.
Recognizes the Aurora Borealis and calls it the Bi-Frost, showing awareness and knowledge.
Makes his way through the other Vikings and commands them to wake up.
Blows the Horn gently and smiles at Aud, sharing a moment of connection and trust.
Stares bewitched and begins to climb out of the ship despite Aud's attempt to pull him back.
Recognizes the magical city of Asgaard and confirms its reality despite others' doubts.
Blows the Horn gently and skillfully to awaken the Gods, successfully triggering the magical events.
Begins to climb out of the ship despite Aud's warning, showing possible overconfidence or impatience.
Rejects Aud's offer to come with him despite her insistence and emotional plea, apologizing sincerely.
Decides to continue the dangerous journey alone despite emotional difficulty and the pleas of others.
Expresses hesitation and emotional conflict but ultimately makes a firm decision to proceed.
Shows some indecision and emotional vulnerability when refusing Aud's company.
Slowly explores Valhalla with caution and curiosity, listens attentively to sounds, leads others forward.
Stops the group to listen carefully and observe the unexpected scene of children and domestic life in Valhalla.
Slowly starts to cross the vast floor looking around him, listens carefully to sounds, and leads others to investigate the scene thoughtfully.
Provides a straightforward explanation of Valhalla despite others' skepticism.
Leaps to Helga's side and tries to take her back to the land of the living, showing concern and care.
Takes Helga's hand despite getting covered in dough, showing sincerity and willingness to connect.
Shouts to Odin and pleads for help to stop men killing each other, showing earnestness and concern for others.
Does not show frustration or anger when Odin and Thor dismiss him, remains polite and persistent.
Attempts to revive Helga by asking the Gods to give her life again, showing initiative and hope.
Admits he has not actually tried to ask the Gods for anything before claiming he would.
Takes Helga's hand impulsively and gets covered in dough, showing a lack of situational awareness.
Shouts to Odin to get his attention despite the Gods being dismissive and busy, demonstrating persistence and confidence.
Explains the problem to Odin clearly and appeals to the Gods for help.
Fails to persuade Odin effectively, indicating limited influence or strategic skill.
Appeals to the gods to end fighting and bloodshed, showing concern for others' suffering.
Expresses disappointment when gods refuse to help men love each other, indicating sincerity and hope.
Attempts to reason with Odin and appeals to the gods to end the Age of Ragnarok and stop the fighting and bloodshed.
Insists that the gods should have power over human emotions despite Odin's explanation to the contrary.
Looks around uneasily when others laugh at Odin's comment about men fighting.
Makes a request before returning, showing consideration and thoughtfulness.
Asks for one more request before returning despite the tension and uncertainty around him.
Looks around uneasily with his men when others laugh, showing some uncertainty or lack of confidence.
Looks towards Helga, finding some consolation despite grim circumstances.
Expresses dismay and fear about being trapped in Valhalla, showing vulnerability.
Pales and shows visible fear when confronted with the reality of being trapped in Valhalla forever.
Looks towards Helga, seemingly trying to find some consolation or positive aspect despite the dire situation.
Asks a clarifying question about their fate, indicating some level of awareness and engagement with the situation.
Expresses concern for Helga, saying 'I tried to save you!' and 'I don't know! I just did!'
Refuses help from Snorri to avoid endangering him, saying 'No! Let go, Snorri!' and warning 'You'll be sucked down too!'
Tries to save Helga despite not fully understanding why he cares; resists being sucked into the Pit but ultimately fails.
Manages to smash his axe into the side of the Pit while falling, showing presence of mind and skill under extreme pressure.
Clutches Ivar's leg to hold on during the fall, showing trust and connection.
Screams when his axe is zapped red hot, showing vulnerability and sincerity.
Laughs and expresses joy with others after falling into the pond, showing friendliness and good-naturedness.
Clutches Ivar's leg while dangling over the Pit of Hel, shows fear but maintains grip.
Screams and lets go of his red-hot axe when Thor zaps it with lightning.
Expresses disbelief and joy upon safely returning home, showing emotional resilience.
Hesitates but reluctantly throws down his weapons to protect the women and children.
Is paralyzed and unable to act decisively when Halfdan threatens to shoot children.
Hesitates but ultimately surrenders weapons to protect the group, showing reluctant but pragmatic decision-making under threat.
Is paralyzed and unable to act decisively when Halfdan threatens to shoot children, showing lack of immediate effective response in crisis.
Smiles at Aud and holds her to him as they all gaze at the sun returning to the world.
